bibl.title: Report by the Ministry of Health, July 10, 1923

div1.p: This report describes the route and the outbreak of malaria on the steamship “Garth Castle.”

div1.head: Report by the Ministry of Health, July 10, 1923
div1.p:
The steamer referred to by the Secretary of the
International Health Board of the Rockefeller Foundation
is almost certainly the S/S “Garth Castle” of the Union
Castle Company. This ship left Capetown on 27th
February to proceed coastwise via Laurenco Marques,
Beira, Durban, East London, Algoa Bay, Capetown,
the Canaries and Teneriffe to London. She stayed at
Laurenco Marques about 3 days and at Beira more than a
week. She left Capetown on the homeward voyage 27th
March and arrived in London 20th April. The first case
of serious illness occurred on 25th March and between
that date and arrival at the Canaries there were six
deaths among the crew and one among the passengers.

There were in all 20 cases of serious illness
during the voyage and two additional deaths occurred before
arrival in London. The disease in all cases was malignant
malaria the diagnosis being confirmed by blood examinations
made in London on arrival of the ship. Evidence as to
incubation period and symptomatology is sufficient
to negative any suspicion that yellow fever was concerned,
but the cases were of a severe type with complications
such as continuous vomiting, wandering in mind, delirium, coma
and deep jaundice. One patient had an epileptiform attack
followed by coma. It is probable that the infections were
contracted at Beira and Laurenco Marques for it is reported
that in both places mosquitoes were so numerous on the ship
that several of the crew had to be medically treated for the
-2-
effect of bites.
